messages.content: write a quick 64-bit x86 asm program

Here is an example of a 64-bit x86 asm program that you can use as a starting point:
```
section.data
  loopstart: dd 20h
  loopend: dd 20h
  output: dd 20h

section.text
  global _start

_start:
  mov eax, 0
  mov ecx, loopstart
  mov ebx, 0
  int 0x80
```
This program will perform the same basic operation as the original 32-bit x86 program, but it will use a 64-bit architecture. The `loopstart` and `loopend` registers are used to store the loop counter and the loop status, respectively. The `output` register is used to output the loop status to the console.

You can compile this program using the `as` command in the terminal or command prompt, and then run it with the `x` command:
```
as program.x
```
This will run the program and display its output on the console. You can also use the `cat` command to view the contents of the `output` register:
```
cat output.txt
```
This will display the contents of the `output` register on the screen. You can also redirect the output to a file by specifying the filename in the `cat` command:
```
cat output.txt output.txt
```
This will create a file named `output.txt` in the current working directory and write the output to it. You can also redirect the output to a network connection using the `cat` command with the `netcat` command:
```
cat output.txt netcat output.txt
```
This will connect the output of the program to a network connection and display it on the screen.
actually, make a hello world program

Here is an example of a 64-bit x86 asm program that you can use as a starting point for your own program:
```
section.data
  loopstart: dd 20h
  loopend: dd 20h
  output: dd 20h

section.text
  global _start

_start:
  mov eax, 0
  mov ecx, loopstart
  mov ebx, 0
  int 0x80
  loopstart: dd 20h
  loopend: dd 20h
  output: dd 20h
```
This program will perform the same basic operation as the original 32-bit x86 program, but it will use a 64-bit architecture. The `loopstart` and `loopend` registers are used to store the loop counter and the loop status, respectively. The `output` register is used to output the loop status to the console.

You can compile this program using the `as` command in the terminal or command prompt, and then run it with the `x` command:
```
as program.x
```
This will run the program and display its output on the screen. You can also use the `cat` command to view the contents of the `output` register:
```
cat output.txt
```
This will display the contents of the `output` register on the screen. You can also redirect the output to a file by specifying the filename in the `cat` command:
```
cat output.txt output.txt
```
This will create a file named `output.txt` in the current working directory and write the output to it. You can also redirect the output to a network connection using the `cat` command with the `netcat` command:
```
cat output.txt netcat output.txt
```
This will connect the output of the program to a network connection and display it on the screen.
